Book I

Tei2html Test Document

This is a test document, mainly intended to test1 the features implemented in the tei2html XSLT stylesheets. This document serves the dual purpose of helping me to develop new features, and act as a cheat-sheet to look up how certain things are achieved with my stylesheet (yes, I sometimes forget myself).

1 Test of a footnote at the div0 level. ↑

[Contents]

Chapter I

Inline Text Elements

This is a sample paragraph, with[2] some italic and bold text. We continue the test with some Small Caps and, in contrast, some All Small Caps used for acronyms such as HTML or abbreviations as P.M.; some fraktur; and some letterspaced text.1 As you can see, the preceding sentence is followed by a footnote. We can shout in big red letters. We also have a reference to the next chapter. It is very well possible to include some text in hieroglyphs, using in-line images as shown here.

The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog Italic
The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog Bold
The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog Caps and small-caps
The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog All-caps
The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog letter-spaced
The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog mono-spaced

A sample of an embedded audio file (as audio overlay in ePub3 version only): The [2a]sound of a Loon, courtesy of the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service.

‘A sample of quotation marks.’

“A sample of hanging punctuation2.”

“ ‘A sample of double quotation marks.’ ”

“Lines of verse

Using hanging punctuation

Are shown here.”

“A sample of quotation marks in bold, excluding the marks.”

“A sample of quotation marks in bold, including the marks.”

‘Test of hanging punctuation using class(hangq).’

‘Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipisicing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exercitation ullamco laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat. Duis aute irure dolor in reprehenderit in voluptate velit esse cillum dolore eu fugiat nulla pariatur. Excepteur sint occaecat cupidatat non proident, sunt in culpa qui officia deserunt mollit anim id est laborum.’

“Test of hanging punctuation using class(hangqq).”

“Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipisicing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exercitation ullamco laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat. Duis aute irure dolor in reprehenderit in voluptate velit esse cillum dolore eu fugiat nulla pariatur. Excepteur sint occaecat cupidatat non proident, sunt in culpa qui officia deserunt mollit anim id est laborum.”

‘ “Test of hanging punctuation using class(hangqqq).” ’

‘ “Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipisicing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exercitation ullamco laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat. Duis aute irure dolor in reprehenderit in voluptate velit esse cillum dolore eu fugiat nulla pariatur. Excepteur sint occaecat cupidatat non proident, sunt in culpa qui officia deserunt mollit anim id est laborum.” ’

Here we have a reference to page 2. We also have a reference to a figure.

In this section we will see a correction, an insertion and a deletion, an abbreviation: USA, a currency amount: $3.90, and a measurement: 10 in. Also included a gap: [missing text] and a gap that is about 10 words long: [missing text].

Test of the choice element as used for transcription: Original.

Books created with these stylesheet include: De Wereld voor de schepping van den mensch by Camille Flammarion, and The Later Life by Louis Couperus (note how this last links points to chapter XIX of the book). Books will be posted at Project Gutenberg. Text can include references to WorldCat or OpenLibrary catalog entries, for example: OLN and OCLC. The code knows short-hand notations for references to such common things as Wikipedia (even in Dutch) and the Bible. (Alternatively, via a prefix defined in prefixDef elements in the TeiHeader: TEI or prefixDef.)

[Contents]

Different ways of including files.

The following paragraph should include some Russian.

First included paragraph (some Russian: русский язык).

The following paragraph should include some Greek.

Second included paragraph (some Greek: ελληνική γλώσσα).

The following paragraph should include some Sanskrit.

Third included paragraph (some Sanskrit: संस्कृतम्).

The following includes the entire file.

Languages written in a different script.

First included paragraph (some Russian: русский язык).

Second included paragraph (some Greek: ελληνική γλώσσα).

Third included paragraph (some Sanskrit: संस्कृतम्).

2 “Note with quotation marks.” ↑

Chapter II

Block-level Text Elements

This is the argument of this chapter, a block of text giving a short kind of index to the chapter.

“Ils partent; et loin d’eux repoussant la barrière,

Ils fendent dans les airs les nuages mouvans,

Et de leurs piés ailés ils devancent les vents.”

(Metamorphoses d’Ovide).

This chapter demonstrates some block-level text elements that can occur in a book.

Section head in quoted material

This is a paragraph in quoted material1 This paragraph contains a footnote, to verify correct handling of this convoluted situation during the transformation.

[Contents]

Letters, Closers, and Openers

A quoted letter is shown below.

23 June 1893
Dear John:

Test of letter. Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipisicing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exercitation ullamco laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat. Duis aute irure dolor in reprehenderit in voluptate velit esse cillum dolore eu fugiat nulla pariatur. Excepteur sint occaecat cupidatat non proident, sunt in culpa qui officia deserunt mollit anim id est laborum.

Dr. May

Chapter IV

Tables

In this chapter we generate a table:1

1 (this cell is actually spanning two rows) 2 (with a much wider cell, for a change, so that we can verify the result of such wide cells in the output)
4
5 (yet another wide cell, just to see how it works out in the result formatting) 62
7: A cell spanning no less than two columns. This should work out fine, even with a footnote2 in it. (note how the footnote reference mark actually is the same as in a cell above, we can also reference to the same footnote without2 such a special treatment!)

We can also place tables3 in footnotes.4

A table with vertical borders on the inside class(verticalBorderInside):

No. Type. Quantity.
kg
1 Apples 12.4
2 Bananas 22.8
3 Melon 4.6
4 Grapes 9.2

The same table with borders on the outside class(borderOutside):

No. Type. Quantity.
kg
1 Apples 12.4
2 Bananas 22.8
3 Melon 4.6
4 Grapes 9.2

The same table with all cell borders shown class(borderAll):

No. Type. Quantity.
kg
1 Apples 12.4
2 Bananas 22.8
3 Melon 4.6
4 Grapes 9.2

The following table is centered:

Gadgets Both 1
Fudgets

But this table is just indented 2 em.

Een Een Een Een Een Een Een Een Een Een Een Een Twee Twee Twee Twee Twee Twee Twee Twee Twee Twee
Drie Drie Drie Drie Drie Drie Drie Drie Drie Drie Drie Vier Vier Vier Vier Vier Vier Vier Vier Vier Vier Vier

Head above table.

Name Age
Years
Jeroen 40
Rodelyn 30
Joshua 7
Raphael 3

In the following table, we use a TEI extension, that is, the element column to provide rendering attributes that cover an entire column. Since the HTML colspan and col elements are not widely supported, we translate these to class attributes on each cell in the column.

Name Length Weight Notes
Meters Kilograms
Jeroen 1.80 86
Rodelyn — — No Info.
Joshua 1.20
Raphael 1.00
Total 4.00

Setting a table in 3-up format, by using rend="columns(3)". This makes it possible to set tables more compactly when they are tall and narrow.

No. Type. Quantity. No. Type. Quantity. No. Type. Quantity.
kg kg kg
1 Apples 12.4 4 Grapes 9.2 7 Cherries 4.0
2 Bananas 22.8 5 Oranges 2.4
3 Melon 4.6 6 Strawberries 1.0

The same table once more, now using item-order(column-major):

No. Type. Quantity. No. Type. Quantity. No. Type. Quantity.
kg kg kg
1 Apples 12.4 2 Bananas 22.8 3 Melon 4.6
4 Grapes 9.2 5 Oranges 2.4 6 Strawberries 1.0
7 Cherries 4.0

The same table once more, now using without a header:

1 Apples 12.4 4 Grapes 9.2 7 Cherries 4.0
2 Bananas 22.8 5 Oranges 2.4
3 Melon 4.6 6 Strawberries 1.0

The same table a last time, now again using item-order(column-major):

1 Apples 12.4 2 Bananas 22.8 3 Melon 4.6
4 Grapes 9.2 5 Oranges 2.4 6 Strawberries 1.0
7 Cherries 4.0

A table to demonstrate manually applied overrides for the cell-borders (note that removing borders in tables can be tricky, as often the border line is drawn twice for bordered cells neighbouring each other, so you have to override on both sides, as is done below for the cell ‘Bananas’):

No. Type. Quantity. Color.
kg
1 Apples 12.4 Green
2 Bananas 22.8 Yellow
3 Melon 4.6 Dark Green
4 Grapes 9.2 Blue
5 Oranges 2.4 Orange
6 Strawberries 1.0 Red
7 Cherries 4.0 Dark Red

[Contents]

Tables with repeated rows using ditto marks.

The custom way: using a special ditto element:

Number of apples 23
Number,, of,, bananas 34
Number,, of,, pears 45
Number,, of,, pineapples 56
Number» of» oranges 67

The P5 way: using a seg element with an copyOf attribute

Number of apples 23
Number» of» bananas 34
Number» of» pears 45
Number» of» pineapples 56
Number» of» oranges 67

First row, first cell First row, second cell
Second row, first cell Second row, second cell

Years
Jeroen 39
Rodelyn 29
Joshua 6

Chapter V

Figures

You may note the small ornament above the chapter heading, which is included using a rend attribute on the head element of this chapter.

[Contents]

Chapter VI

Lists

In this section, the various types of lists are demonstrated.

First, we start with a simple, unnumbered list. List items can contain all the normal in-line elements, such as notes, corrections, etc.

  • One
  • Two
  • Three
  • Four
  • Five[3]
  • Six1
  • Seven
  • Eight
  • Nine
  • Ten

By specifying the type of the list as ordered, it becomes a numbered list.

  1. One
  2. Two
  3. Three
  4. Four

We can split a list into two columns, by putting columns(2) in the rend attribute.

  • One
  • Two
  • Three
  • Four
  • Five
  • Six
  • Seven
  • Eight
  • Nine
  • Ten
  1. Een
  2. Twee
  1. Drie
  2. Vier
  1. Vijf
  2. Zes
  1. Zeven
  2. Acht

A list with lower case roman numerals, using the n-attribute to set the number value.:

  1. Een
  2. Twee
  3. Achtenveertig
  4. Negenenveertig

A list without bullets or numbers:

  • Een
  • Twee
  • Drie
  • Vier

Similarly, we can split it in three columns as well, using columns(3).

  • One
  • Two
  • Three
  • Four
  • Five
  • Six
  • Seven
  • Eight
  • Nine
  • Ten

And in a different order, by using item-order(column-major).

  • One
  • Four
  • Seven
  • Ten
  • Two
  • Five
  • Eight
  • Three
  • Six
  • Nine

A list with grouping

  • One
  • Two
  • Three
  • Four
    Five
  • Six
  • This italic text will go first Seven This bold text will go last.
    Eight
  • Nine
  • Ten

1 This is a footnote to list-item six. ↑

Chapter VIII

Poetry

This section is to test the rendering of poetry by the TEI stylesheet. The entire poem should appear centered, with all stanza’s aligned. Note that the technique used to center an entire block of text does not work in IE.

(An index reference to a footnote here as well.)

Three stanzas in a row

This is a rule of verse

This is another [5]rule of verse

This is a rule of verse

This is another rule of verse

This is a rule of verse

This is another rule of verse

This is a rule of verse

This is another rule of verse

This is a rule of verse in italics

This is another rule of verse

Two verses, aligned:

Frère Jacques Brother John
1

Frère Jacques, frère Jacques,

Are you sleeping, are you sleeping,
2

Dormez-vous ? Dormez-vous ?

Brother John? Brother John?

Sonnez les matines ! Sonnez les matines !

Morning bells are ringing! Morning bells are ringing!
4

Ding, daing, dong. Ding, daing, dong.

Ding, dang, dong. Ding, dang, dong.

1 To add verse in a footnote, the lg element needs to be enclosed with a q element. This is a requirement of the TEI DTD.

This is a rule of verse in italics in a footnote

Chapter IX

Text Alignments

Hoofdstuk IX

Tekstsynchronisatie

This is a test of printing translated paragraphs side-by-side

Dit is een test van het naast elkaar afdrukken van vertaalde alinea’s

The paragraphs will be numbered using the n attribute.

De alinea’s worden genummerd met het n attribuut.

That way, the style sheet knows which paragraphs belong together.

Op die manier weet de stylesheet welke alinea’s bij elkaar horen.

Als er af en toe een extra alinea tussendoor komt, maakt dat niet uit.

Hebban olla vogala nestas hagunnan hinase hic enda thu. Wat unbidan we nu.

This makes it easy to verify translations.

Dit maakt het eenvoudig vertalingen te controleren.

An extra paragraph, with the translation next to it.

And yet another paragraph.

Een extra alinea, met de vertaling ernaast.

And the final paragraph.

En de laatste alinea.
[Contents]

Nogmaals een test

This is a test of printing translated paragraphs side-by-side, this time the translation is pulled-in from another source.

Dit is een test van het naast elkaar afdrukken van vertaalde alinea’s

Deze alinea staat in een externe bron.

The paragraphs will be numbered using the n attribute.

De alinea’s worden genummerd met het n attribuut.

That way, the style sheet knows which paragraphs belong together.

Op die manier weet de stylesheet welke alinea’s bij elkaar horen.

Als er af en toe een extra alinea tussendoor komt, maakt dat niet uit.

This makes it easy to verify translations.

Dit maakt het eenvoudig vertalingen te controleren.

And yet another paragraph.

And the final paragraph.

This is a test of using CSS using @rendition attributes referencing rendition elements in the TeiHeader.

This is a test of using CSS using a style defined in a rendition element: CSS before should be blue.

This is a test of using CSS using a style defined in a rendition element. The first letter of this paragraph should be large and red.

Mathematical Formula

This is an experimental feature. To include a mathematical formula, just type to get Einstein’s1 famous equation.

Similarly, to get the time-dependent Schrödinger equation, you can type and impress your friends. Okay, lets do one more for the heck of it: (2a)(2a) If you want to learn more about these, go to Wikipedia.

1 That is again, to test handling of duplicate formulas and to demonstrate how they neatly resize, matching the x-height of the surrounding text. ↑

Section 2. Information about the Mission of Project Gutenberg™

Project Gutenberg™ is synonymous with the free distribution of electronic works in formats readable by the widest variety of computers including obsolete, old, middle-aged and new computers. It exists because of the efforts of hundreds of volunteers and donations from people in all walks of life.

Volunteers and financial support to provide volunteers with the assistance they need are critical to reaching Project Gutenberg™'s goals and ensuring that the Project Gutenberg™ collection will remain freely available for generations to come. In 2001, the Project Gutenberg Literary Archive Foundation was created to provide a secure and permanent future for Project Gutenberg™ and future generations. To learn more about the Project Gutenberg Literary Archive Foundation and how your efforts and donations can help, see Sections 3 and 4 and the Foundation information page at www.gutenberg.org Section 3. Project Gutenberg™ depends upon and cannot survive without wide spread public support and donations to carry out its mission of increasing the number of public domain and licensed works that can be freely distributed in machine readable form accessible by the widest array of equipment including outdated equipment. Many small donations ($1 to $5,000) are particularly important to maintaining tax exempt status with the IRS.

The Foundation is committed to complying with the laws regulating charities and charitable donations in all 50 states of the United States. Compliance requirements are not uniform and it takes a considerable effort, much paperwork and many fees to meet and keep up with these requirements. We do not solicit donations in locations where we have not received written confirmation of compliance. To SEND DONATIONS or determine the status of compliance for any particular state visit www.gutenberg.org/donate.

While we cannot and do not solicit contributions from states where we have not met the solicitation requirements, we know of no prohibition against accepting unsolicited donations from donors in such states who approach us with offers to donate.

International donations are gratefully accepted, but we cannot make any statements concerning tax treatment of donations received from outside the United States. U.S. laws alone swamp our small staff.

Please check the Project Gutenberg Web pages for current donation methods and addresses. Donations are accepted in a number of other ways including checks, on-line payments and credit card donations. To donate, please visit: www.gutenberg.org/donate.

Professor Michael S. Hart was the originator of the Project Gutenberg™ concept of a library of electronic works that could be freely shared with anyone. For forty years, he produced and distributed Project Gutenberg™ eBooks with only a loose network of volunteer support.
